critique:
This document is an execution order following a military tribunal after the assassination of President Lincoln. It is difficult to place on the traditional left-right spectrum, as it concerns a specific historical event and legal process rather than broad policy. The order does not directly relate to immigration, economic regulation, or social inclusion in a way that allows for scoring on those axes. The order expands executive power, as it is a direct command from the President to carry out sentences. It also centralizes power at the federal level, as it involves a military division acting under presidential order. The order prioritizes national security in the aftermath of a major national crisis. Therefore:

Ideological Tilt: 0 (Centrist/Moderate)
Immigration Approach: 0 (Balanced/Selective)
Executive Power: 3 (Moderately Expands Executive Authority)
Federalism: 3 (Moderately Strong Federal Control)
National Security vs. Civil Liberties: 3 (Heavy National Security Focus)
Economic Regulation: 0 (Moderate Regulation)
Social Inclusion: 0 (Neutral)
